This course is a general introduction to the nature, history and use of human language, speech and writing. Topics include the biological basis of human language, and analogous systems in other creatures; relations to cognition, communication, and social organization; sounds, forms and meanings in the world’s languages; the reconstruction of linguistic history and the ‘family tree’ of languages; dialect variation and language standardization; language and gender; language learning by children and adults; the neurology of language and language disorders; the nature and history of writing systems. Intended for any undergraduate interested in language or its use, this course is also recommended as an introduction for students who plan to major in linguistics. 

Overall, students were very happy with this course and thought it was “very interesting and informative” and “interesting concepts” were covered. Though sometimes the professors assumed “the students’ basic knowledge was broader than it was really” and “lectures were often not stimulating,” everyone agreed that the “topics were very interesting” and that “the course was very organized.” Students agree that it is a “good intro to linguistics” and they “learned a lot about a subject they knew nothing about.”

Students claim that Professor Embick “would be able to teach this class alone.” He was “engaging and did a great job communicating the subtleties of the course content." Though the “trading off of lectures between the two professors” made the course seem “disjointed,” Professor Embick is considered “a great professor.”

The students agree that this is a “good intro to linguistics” and is a “really easy and efficient way to fulfill an SAS requirement.” Students claim the “workload is very light” and “there were weekly homework assignments.” This course is good for fulfilling the requirement, but also inspired one student to “take further classes in the subject.”
